review_title: Avoid any jobs in the IT Department at ALL COSTS
job_title: Business Intelligence Developer Lead in London, England
pros: Salary is OK but no bonus and payrises are not in line with inflation.
cons:
A real in-depth detailed account of my time at HCA UK below. This is not me moaning but my experience of 3 years at HCA UK IT Department.

In terms of workforce, there are approx. 150 positions in IT, when I left in October 2021, there were approx. 80 vacant positions, leaving the workforce little time or resource to implement mid to long-term strategy, instead always focussed on keeping the lights on. Speaking with ex-colleagues this is still the case in May 2022. 

The IT Department has been through 3 restructures in 4 years. Meaning long-term strategy is very difficult to implement

Little to no documentation across any of legacy development. High turnover of staff meant that a lot of time was spent untangling a complex web of code left behind by predecessors.

Our data team reported to Head of Infrastructure, who didn't have the foggiest idea of what we did as a team and so did not understand our long term strategy. Focus is instead of keeping costs to a minimum. 

There is a clique mentality whereby certain "favoured" teams and persons within the company are given preferential treatment. 

During COVID there was a recruitment freeze and understaffed teams were essentially told to put up and shut up with no regard to the health and wellbeing of their colleagues. I personally suffered with mental health during lockdown as our team was slashed from 9 people to 4, there was little support from upper management regardless of how often the issue was raised. 

I personally was told to "either work more efficiently or take on less work" by management. This was impossible as I was solely focussed on supporting existing developments, this eventually led me to be signed off for 5 weeks work due to stress. When I returned there was little support or acknowledgement from senior managers.

A toxic environment where persons with long standing tenures will make every change you try to implement as difficult as possible. Change Approval Boards and Architectural Review Boards are there so that these people can flex their "power" and to belittle others. One incident stands out whereby a longstanding and very knowledgeable contractor was literally laughed at during one of these meetings.

HR Department were cut-throat. the birth of my first child came early and occurred 4 days prior to me completing my probation period. I only found out when my paycheck was 50% less than expected for the month that the time I had taken off considered unapproved leave. After raising the issue with senior management I was simply told this was company policy. 

Payroll did not pay my taxes correctly so after leaving HMRC sent me an unexpected bill for unpaid taxes. 

Senior management team do not readily engage with rest of IT. Skip level meetings are there but were regularly cancelled and not deemed important (not just mine, but people in other teams as well).

pros:
I continue to stay at HCA and will not consider anywhere else for several reasons:

Development; HCA UK have invested in me and my career, I have been internally promoted twice, had funding for further education and am encouraged to continue to grow as an individual.  This is not uncommon in HCA, there are endless opportunities for individuals to grow internally across the entire group. If you have the right attitude and share the same values, you can go far at HCA if you desire to.  I am one of many.

Company Vision and Management; I have a visible, supportive Senior Management, who communicate what is expected of me and my team. I know exactly our objectives, what we are trying to achieve and why and how this impacts the wider business.  Where change might be needed to try something new, or we might need different tools or resources, they listen. They also recognise our efforts and say thank you and well done regularly. 

Culture; It’s a rewarding environment, I often go home with a sense of accomplishment knowing me and my team made a difference today. We have the tools and resources we need to perform our roles. I work across several teams and different sites, yet we all share the common goal, when you might need support or obstacles to overcome there are lots and lots of colleague to turn to, willing to help and share ideas.  

When you read the patient outcome stories too, it hits you, that whatever your role might be, you played a part of that story and that's why you do what you do.   It's amazing. 

HCA group was set up in 1968,  growing all the time, I have job security and the compensation is very good.
cons:
HCA is constantly striving to maintain excellence. It can be challenging on occasions, but that’s the ethos of HCA, the organisation would not be where it is today, dominating the private healthcare industry, without a committed team of experts, driving high standards. We have CQC ‘outstanding’ ratings for a reason, unrivalled pioneering care, breaking medical innovation records and continued business growth comes with hard work and determination. 

I continue to stay, year after year, as I feel proud to be part of that type of organisation. The challenges you might face are temporary, you will overcome them, it will stretch you and you will grow and you will always come out at the end feeling, it was worth it and the people around you understand that too.

review_title: Think how much more profit you could make if you paid for better staff who made fewer less costly mistakes.
pros: HCA is the dominant private healthcare provider in London.  They make huge profits, but also reinvest heavily to ensure their hospitals are equipped with the latest and best equipment.  In turn this attracts the better doctors thus ensuring better healthcare.  This is good for staff who can be trained in the latest techniques by experts which then allows them to seek better paid positions elewhere.
cons: Very little respect or care is shown for staff, who tend to be treated as resources rather than people.  Salaries tend to be the least the company can get away with.  There are a lot of double standards and window dressing.  There is a published code of conduct, regular training sessions in ethics, statutary training in moving and handling and Fire, etc. but it comes across loud and clear that these sessions are really for the protection of the company rather than individuals.  When it comes down to it we are all just a number.  For instance the senior manager in our central laboratories retired earlier this year after over 30 years of exemplary service, but received no retirement party or leaving present or even an announcement in praise and recognition of his contribution.  Most of us did not know he had left until some time later.  The lab has many outside customers, many of whom commented badly about the way the company had treated him.  Many staff also were left disillusioned.  The company pays poor salaries, but boasts that these are good.  They have a grading system, but very few people seem to be told which scale they are on, and the scales certainly are not available to view.  Because of this there is a high turnover of staff (the highest turnover is apparently in the H/R department itself) and this makes it very difficult for managers who have to constantly train new staff.

Lack of progression - There is a definite lack of fair progression within the corporate teams. I witnessed family members promoting one another, people being misinformed regarding promotion opportunities and unfairness in development opportunities. Unless you are related to a senior member of staff or are friends with them, do not expect to be developed within your role. 

It’s a HR Nightmare – Not even including the points above regarding to the lack of equality in promoting staff, there is general bad behaviour within the corporate staff. This generally came from management and despite a huge number of complaints about this, nothing was ever resolved. I blame this down to the lack of care and interest that came from Senior Management that should have sorted this out. I had witnessed many cases of work-place bullying that were not dealt with effectively and gossiping is rife due to the lack of information, which moves on to my next point…

Nothing is communicated – Rumours spread like wildfire because staff are rarely communicated to about a multitude of things. Everything is always being hidden and everyone seems so uninformed about the things that are going on within their own teams, let alone the business as a whole. 

You may be pulled in by the attractive salary and benefits, however I would seriously think twice about joining this company as the effect it will have on your wellbeing is not worth it.

pros:
I'm trying to be impartial but am really struggling to find a decent pro for the organisation. 

Relative stability throughout recent economic troubles. 

Heavy investment in new medical services
cons:
Substantial problems with how the Legal & HR function is managed and who it is managed by - very damaging to the business; known about but ignored. 

Pension scheme is one of the weakest on the London market. Benefits are so so. 

As is mentioned in another review, the pay is terrible and there is no market matching process meaning that irrespective of what you should be paid, you will not receive this. 

I again second the comments in another review about turnover in the HR function. HR here may as well be called the 'disciplinary' department. This organisation seem to view HR as a means to inflict suffering and misery on their workforce hence the fact that no HR staff stay for longer than absolutely necessary and are usually young and inexperienced for the roles and therefore don't realise how bad what they're being asked to do is. 

There are company policies that state you can be sacked after 10 days continuous sickness (so you cannot be sick when working for a healthcare organisation) and any discretionary benefit (e.g. maternity) is at the statutory minimum. 

Staff training and development generally constitutes a pat on the back. 

The company are very profitable yet share nothing with their employees. Salaries are weak, benefits are primarily employee paid, company policies are to give as little as possible to employees. 

I'd have to assume that the actual patient care side of the business is very good; shame that staff aren't treated in anywhere near the same way!
